channel.title: Linkity Link
channel.description: A curated collection of interesting links by Brad Barrish

item.title: Pinterest's Fall Trend Report
item.description: This fall, Gen Z is driving a powerful shift toward thrifting and sustainable shopping, making secondhand style not only smart, but stylish.

item.title: Scott Alexander on AI psychosis
item.description: Folie a deux ex machina

item.title: The GenAI Divide (PDF)
item.description: An interesting paper from MIT discussing the state of AI in Business from July 2025

item.title: Unfuck Email
item.description: I commend the effort and the name of this project. If my filters weren't so complex, I might be inclined to try this.

item.title: Byte - a visual archive
item.description: An absolutely incredible archive. I read a lot of BYTE as a computer nerd kid.

item.title: MacOS 26 Tahoe’s Dead Canary Utility App Icons
item.description: Absolutely scathing. These are the not the work of carpenters who care about the backs of the cabinets.

item.title: Bounce is a new cross-protocol migration tool
item.description: Cool to see this new tool that uses Bridgy Fed to help migrate your social graph between Mastodon and Bluesky.

item.title: Welcome to "Scamlexity"
item.description: Guardio put agentic AI browsers to the test.

item.title: Opinion | Bring Back the Blue-Book Exam
item.description: In an age of AI, there is a growing effort in academia to return to handwritten assignments. I'm all for it.

item.title: We must build AI for people; not to be a person
item.description: ⁠⁠Consciousness is a critical foundation for our moral and legal rights. So far, civilization has decided that humans have special rights and privileges.⁠

item.title: The sovereign individual and the paradox of the digital age
item.description: Data has created a new and paradoxical social order: the promise of emancipation is made possible by classifying everything.

item.title: How churches use data and AI
item.description: Spiritual care and technology are converging across the country, reshaping the theology of trust.

item.title: The Normal Life of Earl Sweatshirt
item.description: A long, intimate conversation about fatherhood, fascism, and his surprise new album ‘Live Laugh Love.’

item.title: Zvi has some good travel advice
item.description: In honor of Nate Silver’s analysis of when to leave for the airport, and because it’s been an intense week, Zvi offers his thoughts on various related questions.

item.title: Shocker! Companies caught making it harder to delete your personal data online
item.description: Some good journalism from The Markup about how dozens of companies are hiding how you can delete your personal data.

item.title: bitrig
item.description: Impressive! From the folks who created SwiftUI comes a way to build apps for your phone, on your phone.

item.title: Phrack is BACK
item.description: This brings back the serious feels. Wow.

item.title: Covid and Our Arteries
item.description: A new study on acceleration of vascular aging adds to the body of evidence. I have thankfully only had it once that I know of and I hope to avoid getting it again.

item.title: Lab-Grown Salmon Hits the Menu
item.description: The FDA's decision clears the way for the first cultured fish to join the small but growing alternative protein market.

item.title: The peculiar case of Japanese web design
item.description: A deep dive

item.title: The beauty of a text only webpage
item.description: There's something I love about opening a text-only webpage.

item.title: T-Mobile claimed selling location data without consent is legal—judges disagree
item.description: T-Mobile can’t overturn $92 million fine; Even with the fine, I bet they still come out ahead.

item.title: Class-action suit claims Otter AI secretly records private work conversations
item.description: A lot of what this lawsuit talks about is exactly why I cancelled my Otter subscription. Super shady.

item.title: Data Dominates Every Facet of Our Daily Lives
item.description: How to reclaim our humanity

item.title: Claude Code Is All You Need
item.description: Mostly agree. I use Claude Code for a lot and really enjoyed this.

item.title: New eye drops can fix farsightedness
item.description: The FDA approved Vizz, the first-of-its-kind prescription treatment to release later this year. Yay, science! Might have to try.

item.title: Simon's GPT-5 write-up is required reading
item.description: He says GPT-5 is his daily-driver and his new favorite model.

item.title: The arcane alphabets of Black Sabbath
item.description: To commemorate Ozzy, the best fonts site on the web take a deep dive into the obscure sources for the titling designs on Black Sabbath's early album covers.

item.title: Lumo is a privacy-first AI assistant
item.description: Proton made a zero-access encrypted AI assistantthat doesn't track or record your conversations.

item.title: What Kids Told Us About How to Get Them Off Their Phones
item.description: Children who were raised on screens need more freedom out in the real world.

item.title: OpenAI Releases Open Models
item.description: Exciting! These are open-weight reasonaing models that you can download and customize.

item.title: A.I. Is About to Solve Loneliness
item.description: And that's not going to be a good thing. The discomfort of loneliness shapes us in ways we don’t recognize—and we may not like what we become without it.

item.title: Seth's new tool to help you get unstuck
item.description: I love how he's utilizing AI and the combination of physical and digital

item.title: LinkedIn Joins The Parade Of Cowards
item.description: In a surprising-to-no-one move, LinkedIn has quietly joined the parade of corporate cowards rolling back basic protections for transgender users.

item.title: What Happened When I Tried to Replace Myself with ChatGPT in My English Classroom
item.description: What could possibly go wrong?

item.title: Ghost releases 6.0
item.description: If I cared about building an audience, Ghost is the platform on which I would do it.

item.title: Ninety laptops, millions of dollars: US woman jailed over North Korea remote-work scam
item.description: A absolutely bonkers story about a woman involved in identity fraud that amassed millions to allegedly aid nuclear weapons program. WTF?

item.title: The Future is NOT Self-Hosted
item.description: In a world where corporations have detached buying from owning, one man attempts to do something radical: build his own cloud.

item.title: The god of small things
item.description: Celebrating the Estonian composer, Arvo Pärt at 90

item.title: I’m not ignoring your message – I’m overwhelmed by the tyranny of being reachable
item.description: I continue to believe that being reachable is for chumps and luxury means not being reachable

item.title: Manton makes Micro.blog free for teachers and nurses
item.description: Classy. Makes me proud to have my blog on their platform.

item.title: StrumTube does AI-driven chords analysis
item.description: Pretty cool way to learn chords! It will get taen down in 3...2...1...

item.title: Tim Bray's De-Google Project Update
item.description: Google, Apple and others make it insanely difficult to walk away. That's the way they want it.

item.title: The HTML Hobbyist
item.description: The web is for everyone

item.title: How the Solid Protocol Restores Digital Agency
item.description: Schneier on Sir Tim Berners Lee's solution to the current messy state of digital identity.

item.title: Welcome to the copyparty
item.description: Turn almost any device into a file server with resumable uploads/downloads using any web browser

item.title: Learning Is Slower Than You Think — And That’s the Point
item.description: What AI-optimized schools misunderstand about learning

item.title: VSCO launches a stand-alone iOS camera app called Capture
item.description: I haven't used VSCO for a long time, but looking forward to trying this out.

item.title: Someone created a second brain with NotebookLM
item.description: It's something I've considered and should probably just try doing it for a month and see what happens.

item.title: Nobody Knows How To Build With AI Yet
item.description: The future of software development might just be jazz. Everyone improvising. Nobody following the sheet music.
